segments.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kumbho anādhāro suppavattiyo hoti, sādhāro duppavattiyo hoti;
segments.en: “A pot without a stand is easy to overturn, but if it has a stand it’s hard to overturn.

segments.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, cittaṃ anādhāraṃ suppavattiyaṃ hoti, sādhāraṃ duppavattiyaṃ hoti.
segments.en: In the same way, a mind without a stand is easy to overturn, but if it has a stand it’s hard to overturn.
And what’s the stand for the mind?
It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
This is the stand for the mind.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kumbho anādhāro suppavattiyo hoti, sādhāro duppavattiyo hoti;
segments.en: A pot without a stand is easy to overturn, but if it has a stand it’s hard to overturn.

segments.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, cittaṃ anādhāraṃ suppavattiyaṃ hoti, sādhāraṃ duppavattiyaṃ hotī”ti.
segments.en: In the same way, a mind without a stand is easy to overturn, but if it has a stand it’s hard to overturn.”

suttaplex.blurb: Someone without the eightfold path is easily knocked over, like a pot without a stand.
